The intent of this project is to provide ground fault protection at the De Anza College electrical distribution system that serves the Photovoltaic (PV) system “E” at Parking Lots A & B. PG&E requires that a ground fault sensing system be installed now that the Media and Learning Center and Corporation Yard PV systems have been added to the campus-wide electrical power production.  A ground fault sensing system reduces the risk of fire and other safety hazards by detecting electrical currents and shutting down the PV systems if a ground fault is detected.

The Foothill College Paramedic Program, located at the Middlefield campus, requires the purchase of cardiac monitor/defibrillator devices to train its Emergency Medical Technician and paramedic program students.  The program currently has several monitors that represent manufactures used in the pre-hospital setting however; it does not have LifePak systems, which are widely used and prevalent in the local area.  Therefore, District Purchasing Services staff prepared bid documents and incorporated technical specifications for Physio-Control LifePak systems (or equivalent), jointly written with District staff for the purchase of defibrillators for the Middlefield campus paramedic program.  
	 
Invitation to Bid #1697 was advertised in the San Jose Post Record on April 22, 2014, and April 29, 2014.  The ITB was directly sent to four (4) vendors, as well as, posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Purchasing Services staff publicly opened and read the bids on May 22, 2014, at 2 PM.  The bid results are shown below:
	 
					 
Henry Schein, Inc.
Physio-Control, Inc.

The bid documents required that bidders quote all line items listed on the Bid Form.  Henry Schein did not quote all line items.  Therefore, the lowest responsive and responsible bidder is Physio-Control, Inc.  The project is funded from Measure C FF&E.

Background and Analysis:
	 
The scope of work for Project 162 consists of site improvements to better regulate parking and circulation traffic surrounding Foothill campus. The scope of work includes construction of a new staircase from Lot 1 to Lot 1A, replacement of an existing natural gas line under the stairs, and relocation of the main campus gas meter.  The work also includes demolition of hardscape and softscape, new grading, new landscaping, new sidewalks, new lighting, and associated electrical infrastructure.
	 
WRNS Studio prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department. 
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on March 6, 2014, and March 13, 2014.  The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builders’ exchanges, advertised in the San Jose Post Record, and posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on March 20, 2014, and a total of seven (7) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 22, 2013 in the Purchasing Services office.  Two contractors submitted bids and the bid result are summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Base Bid Proposal Amount:
Rodan Builders, Inc.
$708,000
RC Benson & Sons, Inc.
$1,070,000
	 
According to Public Contract Code (PCC), Section 20651(b): “The governing board shall let any contract for a public project, as defined in subdivision (c) of Section 22002, involving an expenditure of fifteen thousand dollars ($15,000) or more to the lowest responsible bidder who shall give security as the board requires, or else reject all bids.” 
	 
The bid submitted by Rodan Builders, Inc. exceeds the architect’s estimate of $535,000.  Therefore, the District recommends that the Board reject the bids received for Bid#1683-162, Parking and Circulation Phase 3, Lot 1 Stairs. A busy construction industry, a low number of bid responses, and the combination of dis-similar types of work likely contributed to the low bidder response.    
	 
A revised bid package will be prepared for the replacement of the natural gas line as a separate project, and a revised scope will be prepared for the new staircase, new grading, new landscaping, new sidewalks, new lighting, and associated electrical infrastructure work.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Title:  Change Order #14
Vendor:  SJ Amoroso Construction
Agreement Date:  March 3, 2013
Campus:  Foothill College
Project Number:  105
Project Name:  Modernization of Learning Support Center, Biology, and General Classrooms
Amount:  $240,000
For:
	 
Repairs to existing corner hip roof beams at buildings 5100, 5400 and 5600 are required due to structural weaknesses (cracks) in the beams that were not identified initially as part of the project scope. These weaknesses were discovered during construction when SJ Amoroso started to repair the building’s gutters and other adjacent glulam beams that were in the original project scope (ref;  attached photo #5). Attached are photos #9 & #10 that indicate the difficulty of access to these beams and provide an idea of the amount of roof removal that is required to implement repairs.
	 
Repair work includes temporary shoring, structural steel plate reinforcing, painting, and a significant amount of roof removal and replacement to implement the repairs.  This change order includes a no-cost time extension to complete the glulam repairs, which will be substantially complete before the Fall quarter begins. The base contract scope will still be completed on time in August.
	 
Completing this work as a change order is necessary because of the potential for structural failure and the necessity to finish the work with minimal disturbance to Fall Quarter classes. Deferring repairs to these roof beams was considered so that the work could be put out to competitive bid but is not recommended due to the delay that would result in completing the work (approximately one year), and the additional costs that would be incurred if the work is done after the current renovation is complete.
	 
This change plus all previously approved change orders equal to 13.5% of the base contract value. The project budget is being augmented by the Foothill Budget Transfer #46 at the June 16, 2014, Board of Trustees Meeting in order to accommodate this change.

The scope of work for Project 100O includes new concrete curb at select perimeter locations of the tennis courts, paving repair and resurfacing of tennis courts, crack repair, removal and replacement of select chain link fence fabric, replacement of ball wall, and adjustment of fence gates. The work for Alternate 1 includes replacement of windscreens and Alternate 2 includes additional removal of existing wood headers and installation of a new concrete curb at select locations. 
	 
Verde Design, Inc. prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
